author: Accenture
title: Government as a Platform
research: 4 models are introduced: whole-of-government platform, peer platform, ecosystem platform, crowdsourcing platform
why-interesting: The four platform framework acknowledges variety in paths taken by different countries or different preferences about how government as a platform should operate

author: Margetts, H. and Naumann, A.
title: Government as a Platform: What can Estonia Show the World?
research: The paper looks at the Estonian case where it has come nearest to being realised
why-interesting: The paper looks at the seven principles named by O'reilly and applies them to the Estonian case and then compares with GDS.

author: ﻿Brown A., Fishenden J., Thompson M., Venters W.
title: Appraising the impact and role of platform models and Government as a Platform (GaaP) in UK Government public service reform: Towards a Platform Assessment Framework (PAF)
research: The paper develops a Platform Appraisal Framework incorporating the various dimensions that characterise business models based on digital platforms.
why-interesting: The paper argues that GaaP is misinterpreted as a solely technological concept.

author: ﻿Janssen Marijn, Estevez, Elsa
title: Lean government and platform-based governance—Doing more with less
research: The paper introduces the concept of lean government where one of its features is platform based thinking. In lean government platforms facilitate exchange with stakeholders.
why-interesting: The paper integrates GaaP  into an overarching theory.

author: Deloitte Access Economics
title: Digital Government Transformation
research: A complete report on the transformation of Australian government
why-interesting: Apart from concrete action steps, discusses challenges of digital transformation

author: Corydon, B., Ganesan, V. and Lundqvist, M.
title: A guide to transforming government
research: A guide on transforming government. The guide also introduces the concept of capabilities (citizen- and business-facing innovations) and enablers (innovations across government systems)

author: Janowski, T.
title: Digital government evolution: From transformation to contextualization
research: The paper presents a model where government transformation evolves through 4 stages Digitization, Transformation, Engagement and Contextualization.
why-interesting: Stage models might be very useful for policy makers and as a way of measuring progress

author: Luna-Reyes, L. F. and Gil-Garcia, J. R.
title: Digital government transformation and internet portals: The co-evolution of technology, organizations, and institutions
research: The paper makes a distinction saying that transformation using digital technologies can be understood twofold: (1) as a transformation of internal processes and (2) as a transformation of the relationships between governments and other social and political actors. It then goes on to argue that there is little evidence of (2) and presents a theory of coevolution of technology, organisational networks and institutional arrangements in the transformation of government.
why-interesting: The paper acknowledges the multifaceted meaning of digital transformation.
